dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, have you ever, like, wondered if ditching your car for ride-shares would actually save you money in the long run?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, have you ever, like, wondered if ditching your car for ride-shares would actually save you money in the long run?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely! I mean, with gas prices, parking, insurance... it feels like it *has* to be cheaper, right? Just call an Uber whenever you need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely! I mean, with gas prices, parking, insurance... it feels like it has to be cheaper, right? Just call an Uber whenever you need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, buckle up, because a new AAA study just dropped, and it's kind of wild. They say city dwellers who rely on ride-hailing are actually paying, on average, over twenty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, buckle up, because a new A A A study just dropped, and it's kind of wild. They say city dwellers who rely on ride-hailing are actually paying, on average, over twenty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, twenty *thousand*? For ride-shares? That's insane! That's like, a car payment, and insurance, and gas, and, like, a vacation!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, twenty thousand? For ride-shares? That's insane! That's like, a car payment, and insurance, and gas, and, like, a vacation!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And get this, they compared it to owning a brand-new car, which, um, they estimate costs about seventy-three hundred bucks annually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And get this, they compared it to owning a brand-new car, which, um, they estimate costs about seventy-three hundred bucks annually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but that's just the car itself, right? That doesn't factor in, like, all the *other* stuff: maintenance, gas, parking fees...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but that's just the car itself, right? That doesn't factor in, like, all the other stuff: maintenance, gas, parking fees...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes outlays for the vehicle itself as well as for operating expenses like fuel, maintenance, repair, financing, insurance, license/registration costs, taxes,and parking fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You got it. And parking is a huge one, especially in big cities. I mean, in New York City, you're looking at over eight *thousand* dollars a year just for the privilege of parking. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You got it. And parking is a huge one, especially in big cities. I mean, in New York City, you're looking at over eight thousand dollars a year just for the privilege of parking. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Eight thousand just for parking? Wow. That's, that's a lot. But still, no insurance, no upkeep... it's gotta be simpler, less hassle with ride-hailing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eight thousand just for parking? Wow. That's, that's a lot. But still, no insurance, no upkeep... it's gotta be simpler, less hassle with ride-hailing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Simpler, maybe, but not cheaper, according to the AAA. Their managing director, John Nielsen, actually said that a personal vehicle is *still* the more cost-effective choice for the average city-dweller, assuming you drive about eleven thousand miles a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Simpler, maybe, but not cheaper, according to the A A A. Their managing director, John Nielsen, actually said that a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice for the average city-dweller, assuming you drive about eleven thousand miles a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, basically, owning a car, even with all the headaches, is still the better financial move for most people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, basically, owning a car, even with all the headaches, is still the better financial move for most people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, pretty much. Unless, of course, you barely drive, or, um, have mobility issues. Then, sure, ride-hailing makes a lot of sense. But for daily commutes and regular use? Not so much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, pretty much. Unless, of course, you barely drive, or, um, have mobility issues. Then, sure, ride-hailing makes a lot of sense. But for daily commutes and regular use? Not so much.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, all this time, I thought I was being smart by *not* owning a car. Turns out I might be spending way more!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, all this time, I thought I was being smart by not owning a car. Turns out I might be spending way more!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] It really makes you think, doesn't it? Even carpooling in a compact car came out ahead financially.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really makes you think, doesn't it? Even carpooling in a compact car came out ahead financially.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the AAA s data, owning a small sedan is the cheapest way to get around town at an average $5,492 to drive the aforementioned 10,841 miles,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, the car is still king, at least for our wallets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, the car is still king, at least for our wallets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For most of us, anyway, it seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For most of us, anyway, it seems.
